original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
Ave. U. south side, on the west bank of the Gerritsen Inlet, showing the Gerritsen Mill.
About 1900.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
Ave. U, south side, west of Garritsen Creek. A view of the Gerritsen House and mill.

1906.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
(1) Ave. U., south side, west of Gerritsen Creek. This property dating from a grant of 1645 to Hugh Gerritsen, has been transferred by wills to the following owners: Rem Gerritsen, Garret Gerritsen, and from Samuel Gerritsen, to Johannes Gerritsen, who in 1765 left it to his son Samuel. He, in 1822, left it to his son John S. and his daughters, Jane and Elizabeth. In 1864, John Samuel Gerritsen left this farm to Samuel J., who in turn left it in 1876 to Mary C., born 1822, and Helen Van Brunt born 1824. In 1864, Samuel J., sold what he did not bequeath to his two daughters, to one Pothemus. All this property in 1879, was purchased by Helen Van Brunt (Mrs. Stephen Harriman). Her heirs conveyed it to William C. Whitney in 1899; and he restored the mill to its original condition in 1900, and vastly improved the house. The first mill was erected in 1656, this one was erected in 1831. Harry Payne Whitney was the last owner. This house and most of the out buildings are on condemned property, which is to be used for Marine Park. 1922. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, the mill and house are to be demolished. The creek will be filled and will be a part of Marine Park. May 12, 1922. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, another view. 1922. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) The same, showing the outbuildings. 1922. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Avenue U - Van Sicklen Street
text:
(1)
Gerritsen's Creek, north of Ave. U.
August 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, a view northeast.
August 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
(1)
Ave. U., south side, west of Gerritsen Creek, showing a house in the foreground, which is in the line of Burnett Street. At some future date it will be either moved or demolished because of the extension of Burnett Street. When the streets are finally cut into this property, the Whitney house which will no longer be in existence would, if standing, be in Marine Park Property at the N.E. corner of Ave. V. and Burnett Street, and the barn would be on the S.W. corner.

August 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, another view.
1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, showing the mill in a view south.
February 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4)
The same, a view south east, showing in the background, the disposal tanks of one of the New York City sewage plants on Ave. W.

September 1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
(1) Ave. U. south side, west of Gerritsen Creek, showing the Gerritsen homestead, later the Whitney estate.
February 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing only the house.
February 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, showing Marsh Street in the foreground. This house was erected in 1830.
September 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) The same, looking north east.
1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Ave. U - Van Sicklen St.
text:
(1) Ave. U (general view) as seen from Ave. S, and across the filled land that once was Gerritsen Creek. This view is south, and shows Gerritsen's Mill just beyond the bridge; which is a portion of Ave. U. This area, today, 1937, is part of Marine Park. May 1927.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) A view northward across the area shown in No. 1. Ave U forms the foreground. February 26, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, a more extensive view. February 26, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(4) The same, further south, showing Gravesend beyond Gerritsen Creek. May 1927.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
